Fix boilerplate text in Apache license This commit updates the Apache license boilerplate with actual information. The Apache license appendix (designed to be removed before publication) states: ``` APPENDIX: How to apply the Apache License to your work. To apply the Apache License to your work, attach the following boilerplate notice, with the fields enclosed by brackets "[]" replaced with your own identifying information. (Don't include the brackets!)... ``` Additionally, the copyright year was not included. Copyright notices must reflect the current year. This commit updates the listed year to 2014. see: http://www.copyright.gov/circs/circ01.pdf for more info

Update license I noticed at the bottom of the license that the placeholder for the year and company wasn't filled in, so I included the current year and the company name. Copyright notices must reflect the current year, so this commit updates the listed year to 2014. See http://www.copyright.gov/circs/circ01.pdf for more info.

Update README.md added Licensing Docker is licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0. See LICENSE for full license text.

Add Developer Certificate of Origin Text We purposely chose to license Docker under the Apache 2.0 license. This is a well-known license, which is popular for its permissive and flexible properties, while still encouraging a collaborative community. It also makes certain representations with regard to contributions, and the rights given to contributors, the project, people who use Docker, people who modify Docker, etc. This approach to contributions is inspired by the popular Linux Developer "Certificate of Origin". This approach makes it simple for new contributors to get started, and avoids bureaucracy in tracking contributions and contributors. To indicate accordance, each individual contribution to the Project is signed off by the developer, using his or her real name, email address, and github handle in the format below: Docker-DCO-1.0-Signed-off-by: Joe Smith <joe.smith@email.com>

Add quick_docker.html Docker Quick Reference page This is an initial version of a summary page for intermediate and advanced docker users. It is developed from github.com/merriam/quick_reference and the guide is under a CC Share-a-like Non-commercial license. It's still improviing, but provides some quick help so far.
